section.title: Systems of Linear Equations in Two Variables

introduction.p: Systems of linear equations are some of the most useful and widely used mathematical tools for solving problems. Systems involving hundreds of variables and equations are not uncommon in applications such as scheduling airline flights or routing telephone calls.

subsection.title: Solving Systems by Graphing
subsection.p: A biologist wants to know the average weights of two species of birds in a wildlife preserve. She sets up a feeder whose platform is actually a scale and mounts a camera to monitor the feeder. She waits until the feeder is occupied only by members of the two species she is studying, doves and blue jays. Then she takes a picture, which records the number of each species on the scale and the total weight registered.

From her two best pictures, she obtains the following information. The total weight of three blue jays and six doves is 48 ounces, and the total weight of five blue jays and two doves is 32 ounces. Using these data, the biologist estimates the average weight of a blue jay and of a dove. She begins by assigning variables to the two unknown quantities:
\amp\text{Average weight of a blue jay:} ~~b
\amp\text{Average weight of a dove:} ~~d

Because there are two variables, the biologist must write two equations about the weights of the birds. In each of the two photos,
(\text{weight of blue jays}) + (\text{weight of robins}) = \text{total weight}
Thus,
3b \amp {}+{} \amp 6d {}\amp={} \amp 48 5b \amp {}+{} \amp 2d {}\amp={} \amp 32

sidebyside.p:
Thus,
3b \amp {}+{} \amp 6d {}\amp={} \amp 48 5b \amp {}+{} \amp 2d {}\amp={} \amp 32
This pair of equations is an example of a linear systemlinear system of two equations in two unknowns (or a 2\times 2 linear system, for short). A solutionsolution to the system is an ordered pair of numbers, (b, r), that satisfies both equations in the system.

subsection.p: Recall that every point on the graph of an equation represents a solution to that equation. A solution to both equations corresponds to a point on both graphs. Therefore, a solution to the system is a point where the two graphs intersect.
We can obtain graphs for the equations in a system quickly and easily using a calculator.

subsection.p: In previous algebra courses, you learned two algebraic techniques for solving 2\times 2 linear systems: substitution and elimination. See Algebra Skills Refresher if you would like to review these techniques.

statement.p: Rani kayaks downstream for 45 minutes and travels a distance of 6000 meters. On the return journey upstream, she covers only 4800 meters in 45 minutes. How fast is the current in the river, and how fast would Rani kayak in still water? (Give your answers in meters per minute.)

li.p: First, we choose variables for the two unknown quantities.
We must write two equations using the variables r and s.

First, we organize the information into a table. When Rani travels downstream, the current in the river helps her, so her effective speed is r+s. When she travels upstream she is fighting the current, so her speed is actually r-s.

Using the formula \text{rate} \times \text{time} = \text{distance}, we write one equation describing Rani's journey downstream, and a second equation for the journey upstream.
(r + s) \cdot 45 \amp = 6000
(r - s) \cdot 45 \amp = 4800
We apply the distributive law to write each equation in standard form.
45r + 45s \amp = 6000 \amp\amp(1)
45r - 45s \amp = 4800 \amp\amp(2)
To solve the system, we eliminate the variable s by adding the two equations vertically.
The speed of the current is \dfrac{40}{3}, or 13\dfrac{1}{3} meters per minute, and Rani's speed in still water is 120 meters per minute.

subsection.title: Inconsistent and Dependent Systems
subsection.p: Because two straight lines do not always intersect at a single point, a 2\times 2 system of linear equations does not always have a unique solution. In fact, there are three possibilities, as illustrated in .

image.description: 3 cases for 3x3 linear system, namely two coincident lines, two parallel lines, or two lines intersecting in a single point

li.p: The graphs may be the same line, as shown in a.
The graphs may be parallel but distinct lines, as shown in b.
The graphs may intersect in one and only one point, as shown in c.

solution.p:
We use the calculator to graph both equations on the same axes, as shown in . First, we rewrite the second equation in slope-intercept form by solving for y.
2x + 2y \amp = 3\amp\amp\text{Substract } 2x \text{ from both sides.}
2y \amp = -2x + 3\amp\amp\text{Divide both sides by 2.}
y \amp = -x + 1.5
Next, we enter the equations as
Y_1 \amp= -X + 5
Y_2 \amp = -X + 1.5

The lines do not intersect within the viewing window; they appear to be parallel. If we look again at the equations of the lines, we recognize that both have slope -1 but different y-intercepts, so they are parallel. Because parallel lines never meet, there is no solution to the system.

subsection.p: A system with no solutions, such as the system in , is called inconsistentinconsistent. A 2\times 2 system of linear equations is inconsistent when the two equations correspond to parallel lines. This situation occurs when the lines have the same slope but different y-intercepts.

statement.p:
Without graphing, show that the following system is inconsistent:
3y = \frac{3}{2}x - 1
2x - 4y = 3

subsection.p: A linear system with infinitely many solutions is called dependentdependent. A 2\times 2 system is dependent when the two equations actually describe the same line. This situation occurs when the two lines have the same slope and the same y-intercept.

solution.p:
We begin by putting each equation in slope-intercept form.
x \amp = \frac{2}{3}y + 3\amp\amp\text{Subtract 3.}
x -3\amp = \frac{2}{3}y \amp\amp\text{Multiply by } \frac{3}{2}.
\frac{3}{2}x-\frac{9}{2}\amp = y
For the second equation,
3x - 2y \amp = 9 \amp\amp\text{Subtract } 3x.
-2y \amp = -3x + 9 \amp\amp\text{Divide by } -2.
y \amp = \frac{3}{2}x - \frac{9}{2}
The two equations are actually different forms of the same equation. Because they are equivalent, they share the same line as a graph, as shown in . Every point on the first line is also a point on the second line, so every solution to the first equation is also a solution of the second equation. Thus, the system has infinitely many solutions.

subsection.p: Here is a summary of the three cases for a 2\times 2 system of linear equations.

li.p: Dependent systemdependent system. All the solutions of one equation are also solutions to the second equation and hence are solutions of the system. The graphs of the two equations are the same line. A dependent system has infinitely many solutions.
Inconsistent systeminconsistent system. The graphs of the equations are parallel lines and hence do not intersect. An inconsistent system has no solutions.
Consistent and independent systemconsistent and independent system. The graphs of the two lines intersect in exactly one point. The system has exactly one solution.

Graph the system

6x + 2y = 15
by hand, using either the intercept method or the slope-intercept method.

subsection.p: It is not always easy to tell from the equations themselves whether there is one solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions. However, the method of elimination will reveal which of the three cases applies.

solution.p:
First, we rewrite the system in standard form as
2x + 3y \amp= 2 \amp\amp (1) 4x + 6y \amp = 7 \amp\amp (2)
We multiply Equation (1) by -2 and add the result to Equation (2) to obtain
This equation has no solutions. The system is inconsistent. (Notice that both lines have slope \dfrac{-2}{3}, but they have different y-intercepts, so their graphs are parallel.)

subsection.title: Applications
subsection.p: Many practical problems involve two or more unknown quantities.

statement.p: A cup of rolled oats provides 11 grams of protein. A cup of rolled wheat flakes provides 8.5 grams of protein. Francine wants to combine oats and wheat to make a cereal with 10 grams of protein per cup. How much of each grain will she need in one cup of her mixture?

row.cell: Fraction of a cup of oats needed:
Fraction of a cup of wheat needed:

li.p: Because we have two variables, we must find two equations that describe the problem. It may be helpful to organize the information into a table.

The wheat and oats together will make one cup of mixture, so the first equation is
x + y = 1
The 10 grams of protein must come form the protein in the oats plus the protein in the wheat. This gives us a second equation:
11x + 8.5y = 10
We now have a system of equations.

We will solve the system by graphing. First, solve each equation for y in terms of x to get
y \amp= -x + 1
y \amp = (10 - 11x)/8.5
Although we could simplify the second equation, the calculator can graph both equations as they are. We know that x and y represent fractions of one cup, so we set the window (as shown in ) with
\text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 0.94
\text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 1
The lines intersect at (0.6, 0.4), which we can verify by substituting these values into the original two equations of our system.
Francine needs 0.6 cup of oats and 0.4 cup of wheat.

statement.p:
Etienne plans to open a coffee house, and he has \$7520 to spend on furniture. A table costs \$460, and a chair costs \$120. Etienne will buy four chairs for each table. How many tables can he buy?
Let x represent the number of tables Etienne should buy, and let y represent the number of chairs. Write an equation about the cost of the furniture.
Write a second equation about the number of tables and chairs.
Graph both equations, solve the system, and answer the question in the problem. (Find the intercepts of the graphs to help you choose a window.)

li.p: x = 8, y = 32. Etienne should buy 8 tables and 4 chairs.

subsection.p: Being unable to read exact coordinates from a graph is not always a disadvantage. In many situations, fractional values of the unknowns are not acceptable.

statement.p: The mathematics department has \$40,000 to set up a new computer lab. The department will need one printer for every four terminals it purchases. If a printer costs \$560 and a terminal costs \$1520, how many of each should the department buy?

li.p: Since the math department needs four times as many terminals as printers, t=4p The total cost of the printers will be 560p dollars, and the total cost of the terminals will be 1520t dollars, so we have 560p + 1520t = 40,000

We solve the second equation for t to get t=(40,000 - 560p)/1520 Now we graph the equations
Y_1 \amp =4X
Y_2 \amp =(40000 - 560X)/1520
on the same set of axes. The second graph is not visible in the standard graphing window, but with a little experimentation we can find an appropriate window setting. The WINDOW values used for are
\text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 9.4
\text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 30
The lines intersect at approximately (6, 24). These values satisfy the first equation, but not the second.
560(\alert{6})+1520(\blert{24})\amp\stackrel{?}{=}40,000
39,840 \amp\ne 40,000

li.p: The exact solution to the system is \left(\dfrac{500}{83},\dfrac{2000}{83}\right). But this solution is not of practical use, since the math department cannot purchase fractions of printers or terminals. The department can purchase 6 printers and 24 terminals (with some money left over).

statement.p:
The manager for Books for Cooks plans to spend \$300 stocking a new diet cookbook. The paperback version costs her \$5, and the hardback costs \$10. She finds that she will sell three times as many paperbacks as hardbacks. How many of each should she buy?
Let x represent the number of hardbacks and y the number of paperbacks she should buy. Write an equation about the cost of the books.
Write a second equation about the number of each type of book.
Graph both equations and solve the system. (Find the intercepts of the graphs to help you choose a window.) Answer the question in the problem.

li.p: x = 12, ~y = 36. The manager should buy 12 hardbacks and 36 paperbacks.

subsection.title: An Application from Economics
subsection.p: The owner of a retail business must try to balance the demand for his product from consumers with the supply he can obtain from manufacturers. Supply and demand both vary with the price of the product: Consumers usually buy fewer items if the price increases, but manufacturers will be willing to supply more units of the product if its price increases.

The demand functiondemand function gives the number of units of the product that consumers will buy in terms of the price per unit. The supply functionsupply function gives the number of units that the producer will supply in terms of the price per unit. The price at which the supply and demand are equal is called the equilibrium priceequilibrium price. This is the price at which the consumer and the producer agree to do business.

statement.p: A woolens mill can produce 400x yards of fine suit fabric if it can charge x dollars per yard. The mill's clients in the garment industry will buy 6000 - 100x yards of wool fabric at a price of x dollars per yard. Find the equilibrium price and the amount of fabric that will change hands at that price.

li.p: The supply equation tells us how many yards of fabric the mill will produce for a price of x dollars per yard. y=400x The demand equation tells us how many yards of fabric the garment industry will buy at a price of x dollars per yard. y = 6000 - 100x

We graph the two equations on the same set of axes, as shown in . We set the window values to
\text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 94
\text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 6200
and use the TRACE or the intersect command to locate the solution. The graphs intersect at the point (12, 4800).

li.p: The equilibrium price is \$12 per yard, and the mill will sell 4800 yards of fabric at that price.
